data.title: Former Thai PM arrives at court for verdict
data.description:
(2 Aug 2017) Two former Thai Prime Ministers arrived in court in Bangkok on Wednesday ahead of a verdict in a case filed against them over a decision to move against protesters outside parliament in October 2008, 
Two people were killed and hundreds wounded in the violence.
Somchai Wongsawat was prime minister and Chavalit Yongchaiyudh his deputy at the time.
The clashes turned violent after police fired tear gas to disperse protesters who were trying to block Somchai from delivering his first policy statement to lawmakers.
Somchai was finally able to enter the parliament building but was then trapped inside when the protesters regrouped and blocked the exits.
He had been prime minister for two weeks when the incident happened. 
The protesters wanted him out because they said he was a proxy for Thaksin Shinawatra, who had been deposed in a military coup two years before. 
Somchai is Thaksin's brother-in-law.
Critics of the current military government see the prosecution against Somchai as a further attempt to remove the Shinawatra family from Thai political life.

data.title: Libya top of agenda for Egyptian and Algerian FMs
data.description:
(2 Aug 2017) LEADIN:
The Egyptian And Algerian Foreign Ministers have both advocated for a peaceful political solution for Libya following meetings in Cairo.
STORYLINE:
The Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry meets with Abdelkader Messahel in the Egyptian Foreign Ministry in Cairo.
Messahel is on a two-day visit to Egypt to pass on a written message from the Algerian President Abdelaziz Bouteflika to the Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sissi.  He will also meet with Egyptian senior officials to discuss ways to boost bilateral co-operation between the two countries.
During the meeting the Foreign Ministers international issues and regional concerns, including the ongoing situation in Libya, are top of the agenda.
At a news conference afterwards, both ministers say they want a peaceful political solution for Libya.
Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry says he hopes Libya will find stability soon.
"All our efforts are focused on achieving one goal - which is getting Libya and its institutions back on track to be able to confront terror threats and meet the needs of the Libyan people," he says.
Algerian Foreign Minister Abdelkader Messahel says the two countries will work together to help Libya.
"It is very important for Egypt and Algeria to coordinate. Regarding Libya, we support a political solution for the Libyan people because there is no other way except dialogue between the Libyans," he says.
Libya has been unstable following the 2011 civil war which toppled and killed the former Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. 
The oil-rich nation is now split between rival governments and militias.

data.title: Afghans decry foreign attacks after mosque bomb
data.description:
(2 Aug 2017) Relatives of those killed in a suicide attack at a Shiite mosque in Herat, Afghanistan held a protest on Wednesday at the scene of the bombing.
They denounced the US, the Taliban and Islamic State group and called on the government to do more to protect the people.
A suicide attacker opened fire inside the mosque packed with worshippers at evening prayers on Tuesday, before detonating his explosives. 
A second explosion came 10 minutes later.
No one has claimed responsibility for the bombing in western Herat province but it came a day after the Islamic State group warned it would attack Shiites.
Along with the 30 killed, 64 people were wounded, 10 of them critically.

data.title: NGO helps refugee children through music
data.description:
(2 Aug 2017) LEADIN:
Refugee children, including those from Syria, who live in camps around Athens in Greece have taken part in a concert at the ancient Theatre of Herodes of Atticus.
The concert was part of the 'Athens and Epidaurus Festival' and was run by the Sistema Europe Youth Orchestra (SEYO), part of the worldwide music organisation El Sistema.
STORYLINE:
This young lady is about to have her moment in the spotlight.
She and some of the other children from Skaramagas Camp in Piraeus, Athens are getting ready to perform.
They are travelling by bus to the ancient Theatre of Herodes of Atticus, which sits next to the Acropolis in Athens.
Gamkin Abdo, a 12 year old boy from Syria, is going too.
The children sing on the bus and are happy and excited to be at the venue.
Inside Gamkin says singing and taking part in the concert makes him feel great.
"I feel good when I am going to the concert. Now I am going to a concert and it's good, and when I sing I feel better, I feel like something."
The concert is part of the worldwide El Sistema music movement.
El Sistema is a music education programme, which was initially founded in Venezuela, and has since spread to 55 countries. 
According to the El Sistema USA website, "El Sistema is a tested model of how a music program can both create great musicians and dramatically change the life trajectory of hundreds of thousands of a nation's neediest kids."
In Greece the mission of El Sistema is to use music as tool for integration. 
The El Sistema Greece programme started in November 2016 and offers a free music programme to refugees. 
Founder of El Sistema, Greece Anis Barnat says hosting the concert at the theatre brings people together.
"It's one of the most ancient theatres in the world, and here Athens is of course the birth of democracy. So coming here is very, very symbolic, We want to show that that all these kids from so many different origins, nationalities, religions, they can do something all together, and be in the same tune."
Barnat says the orchestra and choir are tools the children use for wider learning.
"Music is only an excuse, but with music you can learn so many different things. You can learn mathematics, you can learn, languages, you can learn so many, many tools. You can have tools in your life that will be used as a citizen," he says.
Sistema Europe Youth Orchestra (SEYO) has 190 musicians between the ages of 10 and 20 as well as 30 music teachers from from 27 countries. 
One of the conductors, Ron Davis Alvarez, is also the artistic director of El Sistema Sweden.
He says being involved in a choir and orchestra teaches a child many things.
"One of the important things when you have an orchestra or choir, it is a community. Inside of the community and through the music you learn values, your learn respect you learn how to listen and respect each other. So using the music as a tool for social development and for social integration like the orchestra, El Sistema Europe orchestra, (with which) we are playing today, I think is a good example of how we can communicate, how we can really help each other through music," he says.
Davis Alvarez says he has a lifetime of El Sistema learning.
"El Sistema helped me quite a lot to have a better life. And when I see kids come, refugees that come from an other countries, escape from countries where there are a lot of problems and war, I can see the music can really help them to improve their life," he says.
Gamkin and the children from Skaramagas Camp sing enthusiastically in the choir.
The concert featured works by Handel, Brahms, Tchaikovsky and Beethoven, amongst others.

data.title: Election company: Venezuela result was tampered
data.description:
(2 Aug 2017) The turnout figures in Venezuela's Constituent Assembly election were "tampered with", the director of a company that provides electoral support services to the country said on Tuesday.
Speaking in London, Antonio Mugica, the CEO and Director of Smartmatic, said the company estimated "the difference between the actual participation and the one announced by the authorities is at least one million votes"
Smartmatic was a company created by Venezuelans in Caracas providing electronic voting machines to the late President Hugo Chavez. In recent years it has branched out to provide the same services to countries across the world, while continuing to provide support for elections in Venezuela.

Many people accuse the ruling party of corruption and mismanagement.
Tensions have escalated since government-allied electoral authorities said more than eight million people voted on Sunday, a turnout figure that was disputed by the opposition and independent analysts and condemned by many nations in the region and beyond.

data.title: Provence's iconic lavender fields hit by drought
data.description:
(2 Aug 2017) LEADIN:
France's famous lavender fields are suffering, blighted by drought and disease-carrying insects. 
Scientists and farmers in Provence are now taking steps to preserve this symbol of their region, which is precious source of income for many.
STORYLINE:
Lavender as far as the eye can see, its heady scent attracting insects and tourists alike. 
These vast purple fields have become a symbol of the region of Provence, in southeastern France. 
Commercially, these crops are sought-after by the perfume and cosmetics industry and they are an important draw for tourists. 
Two types of lavender are commonly cultivated in France, Lavandula angustifolia and the hybrid lavender plants known as lavandins (lavandula x intermedia).
But Provence's lavender is feeling the impact of climate change.
Since the early 2000s, local scientists say dry weather has been shortening the lavender's lifespan.
The dry conditions also create a favourable environment for leafhoppers, insects that carry a disease that affects the plants. 
Eric Chaisse is the Technical and Administrative Director of Crieppam, a Provence-based scientific institute dedicated to agricultural research, which is part-funded by the 
French Agriculture Ministry. 
"Lavender in Provence is effectively endangered, because in recent years the plant has been subjected to the effects of climate change that brought a lot less rainfall in the spring and mostly in the autumn," he says. 
"This played a role on the lavender's lifespan. There's also a small cicada (insect), a micro-bacteria transmitting leafhopper. It adapts itself very well to the dryness and it becomes more numerous with very dry weather."
The problem is immediately obvious in this field at harvest season. 
The once seamless rows of lavender are now separated by large holes, which are getting bigger as the lavender plants keep shrinking.
An even closer look reveals the weakened plants grow fewer flowers than healthier versions.  
"Instead of having very long plant ears with a number of large flowers, we have smaller plant ears. The ear is underdeveloped and is either missing or weakened, so so we have a lot fewer of the noble parts of the plant that are the source of the essential oil," says Chaisse. 
The situation is made worse by a leafhopper insect that carries phytoplasma, a bacterial parasite that attacks the plant tissue. 
"The leafhopper is responsible for directly transmitting the phytoplasma disease. This illness sets in on healthy plants, infects them and grows into the plant, in the sap, slowly causing its death," Chaisse explains. 
Plants affected by the condition turn a pale green or yellowish colour and produce smaller leaves with no flowers, says Chaisse. 
The deterioration of lavender plants started with a series of dry weather spells between 2003 and 2007, he says. 
The region enjoyed more rainfall from 2012 to 2014, but drought hit the lavender again last year. 
A lack of rainfall during the autumn of 2016 and this past spring further exacerbated the situation, leading to a higher plant mortality, says Chaisse. 
Typical of Mediterranean areas, lavender historically plays an important role in the economy of Provence, with almost 26,000 producers directly or indirectly involved in the lavender industry.
The region is also internationally renowned for its production of essential oils obtained from the distillation of lavender plants.
Jean-Marie Naud is a farmer producing Lavandula angustifolia and lavandin in the village of Eurre, in southeastern France. 
Naud started cultivating the plant 25 years ago. 
In order to preserve its purity, he says, he's adopted traditional methods that include harvesting by hand.

data.description:
(2 Aug 2017) The Taliban have claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing attack earlier in the day on a NATO convoy in southern Afghanistan.
Qari Yusuf Ahmadi, Taliban spokesman in southern Afghanistan, claimed two armored tanks were destroyed and that 15 foreign soldiers were killed in Wednesday's attack on the outskirts of the city of Kandahar. 
The insurgents, however, routinely exaggerate their gains and death tolls.
US military spokesman Lt. Damien E. Horvath had earlier confirmed the attack and said that there were casualties, but he could not say how many or provide their nationalities
Ahmadi identified the suicide attacker as Taliban fighter Asadullah Kandahari from southern Kandahar, saying he was a "hero" who carried out the attack with a small pick-up truck, packed with explosives.
Kandahar province was the Taliban spiritual and leadership headquarters during their five-year rule that ended in with the US invasion in 2001.

data.title: 51-carat diamond dazzles crowds ahead of online auction
data.description:
(2 Aug 2017) LEADIN:
A large diamond is wowing crowds in Moscow ahead of an online auction later this year.
The 51.38-carat diamond is part of a dazzling $10 million USD collection, crafted from one large 179-carat rough diamond discovered in 2015.
STORYLINE: 
From the mines of Sakha to the bright lights of Moscow.
Part state-owned Russian diamond mining company Alrosa is unveiling the 'Dynasty', a dazzling collection of five diamonds expected to fetch around $10 million USD at auction.
The five sparkling diamonds have been cut and polished from one 179-carat rough diamond discovered in a mine in the northeast Russian republic of Sakha in 2015. 
Diamonds extracted from the Nyurbinskaya pipe in Sakha are thought to be 365-390 million years old.
The large diamond was named 'The Romanovs', after Russia's imperial royal family.
The collection took a year and a half to create.
"These are five diamonds, carved out of a unique diamond, which was extracted from one of our pipes in Nyurbinskaya," explains Alrosa president Sergey Ivanov.
Its centrepiece is a 51.38-carat traditional round brilliant-cut diamond, named 'The Dynasty'.
It's claimed to be the purest and most expensive of all large diamonds manufactured throughout Russian jewellery history.
"This is a unique diamond with exclusive purity, colour and transparency," says director of Diamonds Alrosa, Pavel Vinikhin.
"And such diamonds of extremely high quality have never before been produced throughout the whole history of Russia, including Imperial Russia, the Soviet Union and modern Russia."
Arlosa named the collection 'The Dynasty' in a bid to pay tribute to Russia's renowned jewellers.
Other diamonds in the collection are named after dynasties that played a crucial role in the development of Russian jewellery.
The second by weight, a 16.67-carat round brilliant-cut diamond, is named 'The Sheremetevs'. 
'The Orlovs' is a 5.05-carat oval diamond, 'The Vorontsovs' is a 1.73-carat pear-cut diamond and 'The Yusupovs' is a 1.39-carat diamond.
Diamonds Alrosa hope to fetch at least $10 million for this collection says Ivanov.
'The Dynasty' collection is set to visit Hong Kong and Israel before an online auction in November.
"We developed a new way of selling such a unique collection of diamonds, which is through an online auction on the Alrosa website through a screening format," explains Alrosa sales director Anna Fedotova.
"Registered clients will, after going through a background check, which is a necessary step to attract the right kind of clients to our organisation, will be able to place their bids from any place in the world."

A large diamond is wowing crowds in Moscow ahead of an online auction later this year.
The 51.38-carat diamond is part of a dazzling $10 million USD collection, crafted from one large 179-carat rough diamond discovered in 2015.
STORYLINE: 
From the mines of Sakha to the bright lights of Moscow.
Part state-owned Russian diamond mining company Alrosa is unveiling the 'Dynasty', a dazzling collection of five diamonds expected to fetch around $10 million USD at auction.
The five sparkling diamonds have been cut and polished from one 179-carat rough diamond discovered in a mine in the northeast Russian republic of Sakha in 2015. 
Diamonds extracted from the Nyurbinskaya pipe in Sakha are thought to be 365-390 million years old.
The large diamond was named 'The Romanovs', after Russia's imperial royal family.
The collection took a year and a half to create.
"These are five diamonds, carved out of a unique diamond, which was extracted from one of our pipes in Nyurbinskaya," explains Alrosa president Sergey Ivanov.
Its centrepiece is a 51.38-carat traditional round brilliant-cut diamond, named 'The Dynasty'.
It's claimed to be the purest and most expensive of all large diamonds manufactured throughout Russian jewellery history.
"This is a unique diamond with exclusive purity, colour and transparency," says director of Diamonds Alrosa, Pavel Vinikhin.
"And such diamonds of extremely high quality have never before been produced throughout the whole history of Russia, including Imperial Russia, the Soviet Union and modern Russia."
Arlosa named the collection 'The Dynasty' in a bid to pay tribute to Russia's renowned jewellers.
Other diamonds in the collection are named after dynasties that played a crucial role in the development of Russian jewellery.
The second by weight, a 16.67-carat round brilliant-cut diamond, is named 'The Sheremetevs'. 
'The Orlovs' is a 5.05-carat oval diamond, 'The Vorontsovs' is a 1.73-carat pear-cut diamond and 'The Yusupovs' is a 1.39-carat diamond.
Diamonds Alrosa hope to fetch at least $10 million for this collection says Ivanov.
'The Dynasty' collection is set to visit Hong Kong and Israel before an online auction in November.
"We developed a new way of selling such a unique collection of diamonds, which is through an online auction on the Alrosa website through a screening format," explains Alrosa sales director Anna Fedotova.
"Registered clients will, after going through a background check, which is a necessary step to attract the right kind of clients to our organisation, will be able to place their bids from any place in the world."

data.title: Provence's iconic lavender fields hit by drought
data.description:
(2 Aug 2017) LEADIN:
France's famous lavender fields are suffering, blighted by drought and disease-carrying insects. 
Scientists and farmers in Provence are now taking steps to preserve this symbol of their region, which is precious source of income for many.
STORYLINE:
Lavender as far as the eye can see, its heady scent attracting insects and tourists alike. 
These vast purple fields have become a symbol of the region of Provence, in southeastern France. 
Commercially, these crops are sought-after by the perfume and cosmetics industry and they are an important draw for tourists. 
Two types of lavender are commonly cultivated in France, Lavandula angustifolia and the hybrid lavender plants known as lavandins (lavandula x intermedia).
But Provence's lavender is feeling the impact of climate change.
Since the early 2000s, local scientists say dry weather has been shortening the lavender's lifespan.
The dry conditions also create a favourable environment for leafhoppers, insects that carry a disease that affects the plants. 
Eric Chaisse is the Technical and Administrative Director of Crieppam, a Provence-based scientific institute dedicated to agricultural research, which is part-funded by the 
French Agriculture Ministry. 
"Lavender in Provence is effectively endangered, because in recent years the plant has been subjected to the effects of climate change that brought a lot less rainfall in the spring and mostly in the autumn," he says. 
"This played a role on the lavender's lifespan. There's also a small cicada (insect), a micro-bacteria transmitting leafhopper. It adapts itself very well to the dryness and it becomes more numerous with very dry weather."
The problem is immediately obvious in this field at harvest season. 
The once seamless rows of lavender are now separated by large holes, which are getting bigger as the lavender plants keep shrinking.
An even closer look reveals the weakened plants grow fewer flowers than healthier versions.  
"Instead of having very long plant ears with a number of large flowers, we have smaller plant ears. The ear is underdeveloped and is either missing or weakened, so so we have a lot fewer of the noble parts of the plant that are the source of the essential oil," says Chaisse. 
The situation is made worse by a leafhopper insect that carries phytoplasma, a bacterial parasite that attacks the plant tissue. 
"The leafhopper is responsible for directly transmitting the phytoplasma disease. This illness sets in on healthy plants, infects them and grows into the plant, in the sap, slowly causing its death," Chaisse explains. 
Plants affected by the condition turn a pale green or yellowish colour and produce smaller leaves with no flowers, says Chaisse. 
The deterioration of lavender plants started with a series of dry weather spells between 2003 and 2007, he says. 
The region enjoyed more rainfall from 2012 to 2014, but drought hit the lavender again last year. 
A lack of rainfall during the autumn of 2016 and this past spring further exacerbated the situation, leading to a higher plant mortality, says Chaisse. 
Typical of Mediterranean areas, lavender historically plays an important role in the economy of Provence, with almost 26,000 producers directly or indirectly involved in the lavender industry.
The region is also internationally renowned for its production of essential oils obtained from the distillation of lavender plants.
Jean-Marie Naud is a farmer producing Lavandula angustifolia and lavandin in the village of Eurre, in southeastern France. 
Naud started cultivating the plant 25 years ago. 
In order to preserve its purity, he says, he's adopted traditional methods that include harvesting by hand.

data.title: Bosnia swelters in scorching heat
data.description:
(2 Aug 2017) Scorching heat continued to sweep parts of the Balkans, with some parts of Bosnia recording temperatures of over 42 degrees Celsius (107.6 Fahrenheit).
In the capital of Sarajevo, a young man died of a heart attack while jogging during the warmest time of the day.
Union leaders in Bosnia have called upon all employers to reduce working hours over the next few days, especially for construction workers and those who work mainly outside. 
Meanwhile, a hospital in Zenica closed several of its wards as air conditioning wasn't able to cool off rooms during daytime heat.
The soaring temperatures were expected to continue until mid August.
The elderly and those with chronic heart conditions are being advised to stay indoors during the warmest period of the day.

data.title: Election Company: Venezuela Result was Tampered
data.description:
(2 Aug 2017) The turnout figures in Venezuela's Constituent Assembly election were "tampered with", the director of a company that provides electoral support services to the country said on Tuesday.
Speaking in London, Antonio Mugica, the CEO and Director of Smartmatic, said the company estimated "the difference between the actual participation and the one announced by the authorities is at least one million votes"
Smartmatic was a company created by Venezuelans in Caracas providing electronic voting machines to the late President Hugo Chavez. In recent years it has branched out to provide the same services to countries across the world, while continuing to provide support for elections in Venezuela.
Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro called the vote for the constitutional assembly in May after weeks of protests fed by anger at his government over food shortages, triple-digit inflation and high crime. 
Many people accuse the ruling party of corruption and mismanagement.
Tensions have escalated since government-allied electoral authorities said more than eight million people voted on Sunday, a turnout figure that was disputed by the opposition and independent analysts and condemned by many nations in the region and beyond.

data.title: Pence meets regional leaders in Montenegro
data.description:
(2 Aug 2017) US Vice President Mike Pence is attending a Balkan leaders summit in Montenegro Wednesday.
Tiny Montenegro, which joined NATO earlier this year, is Pence's third stop on a European trip backing nations that feel threatened by Russian influence.
